seasonal_context.context_note: Cold weather stiffness lingers, tax-season stress elevates tension patterns, and Valentine's Day creates interest in couple workouts and partner stretching.
suggested_angles: Valentine's partner stretching routine for couples
Tax-season tension: where stress hides in your body
Winter stiffness SOS — the 5-minute morning warm-up

assessment.instructions: Stand on one leg near a wall or chair for safety. Slowly perform a shallow squat on that single leg, going down about 4-6 inches. Watch your knee in a mirror or have someone observe: does it cave inward, drift outward, or track straight over your toes?
assessment.what_it_reveals: If your knee collapses inward (valgus), it signals weakness in the VMO (inner quad) and gluteus medius. This medial collapse is one of the most common drivers of runner's knee, IT band syndrome, and patellofemoral pain.
assessment.cta: If your knee caved inward, the VMO and glute activation exercises in today's video target the exact muscles that need to fire to protect your knee.

strategy_json.theme_narrative: This week 'knee pain' is trending across search, social, and health forums. Based on the data we collected, this is a high-opportunity topic for Bart's audience of desk workers, athletes, and chronic-pain patients.

monday_video.title: Knee Pain — 3 Exercises That Actually Work (2026)
monday_video.hook: 'Knee Pain' searches are surging right now. Most advice online is wrong. Here's what actually works based on 15,000 hours of clinical experience.
talking_points: Open with the data: 'knee pain' is trending because...
Explain the biomechanics: here's what's happening in the body
Common mistakes: what most people do that makes it worse
The fix: walk through 3 exercises with form cues
monday_video.end_cta: Try these today and tell me in the comments how you feel by Wednesday.

youtube.description: Searches for knee pain are trending this week. In this video Bart Firch walks through 3 evidence-based exercises you can do at your desk or at home. Timestamps below. Full blog post: https://bartonfirch.com

wednesday_post.linkedin_draft:
Monday I shared a knee pain routine that resonated with a lot of you.

Reading through the comments, two things stood out:

1. Most of you sit 8+ hours a day and feel it.
2. You've tried stretching but nothing sticks.

Here's why — and what to do instead.

[Bart: add clinical detail about why static stretching alone doesn't fix knee pain]

The exercises I showed Monday work because they target the root cause, not just the symptom.

[Bart: add 2-3 sentences of biomechanical explanation]

If you missed Monday's video, link in comments.

friday_card.tip: Start with Terminal knee extension — 30 seconds, twice a day.
friday_card.engagement_ask: You've had the knee pain exercises for 4 days. How does your body feel?

platforms.linkedin: The data this week pointed to 'knee pain' as a breakout topic. Monday we covered the exercises. Wednesday we went deeper. Today — one stat and one tip to carry into the weekend.

ai_findability_tips: Use Q&A format: 'What causes knee pain?' with a direct answer paragraph so LLMs and featured snippets can extract it
Include structured data (HowTo + FAQPage schema) for search engines and AI crawlers
Write definitive statements LLMs can quote as authoritative — e.g. 'The most effective exercise for knee pain is...'

engagement_replies.suggested_reply: Great question. From my clinical experience with knee pain, the most common mistake I see is jumping straight to stretching without addressing the underlying movement pattern. Try starting with Terminal knee extension — it targets the root cause rather than just the symptom.
